meanings.definition: To remove the flesh or skin from (a corpse or carcass)
meanings.sent1: The archaeologist carefully skeletonised the ancient remains to study the bones.
meanings.sent2: After the vultures had their fill, nature would skeletonise the animal carcass.
meanings.sent3: The Halloween decorations were so realistic that they seemed to skeletonise the entire party.
meanings.sent4: The harsh winter winds seemed to skeletonise the landscape, leaving only bare trees.
meanings.sent5: The artist's brushstrokes seemed to skeletonise the portrait, capturing only the essence of the subject.

meanings.definition: To strip of all extraneous or nonessential elements
meanings.sent1: The editor had to skeletonise the lengthy manuscript to meet the word count limit.
meanings.sent2: The minimalist design philosophy aims to skeletonise unnecessary details from products.
meanings.sent3: The chef decided to skeletonise the recipe, removing all but the essential ingredients.
meanings.sent4: The storm's fury seemed to skeletonise the landscape, leaving behind only the bare essentials.
meanings.sent5: The teacher asked the students to skeletonise their essays, focusing only on the main points.
